news_summary: The UN chief calls for intensified efforts to complete decolonization and promote self-determination in the remaining 17 territories.
news_summary_fr: Le chef de l'ONU appelle à intensifier les efforts pour achever la décolonisation et promouvoir l'autodétermination dans les 17 territoires restants.
news_summary_es: El secretario general de la ONU insta a intensificar los esfuerzos para completar la descolonización y promover la autodeterminación en los 17 territorios restantes.

articles.title: UN chief urges renewed push to complete decolonization as 17 territories remain
articles.summary: More than 60 years after the UN launched its formal decolonization drive, Secretary-General António Guterres on Monday urged renewed commitment to completing the unfinished business of ending colonial rule.
articles.content:
Since 1945, more than 80 former colonies comprising some 750 million people have gained independence. However, 17 Non-Self-Governing Territories remain on the UN list, home to nearly two million people.

They range from Western Sahara in Africa to small island territories in the Caribbean and Pacific.

A core subject for the UN

Opening the 2026 session of the Special Committee on Decolonization – known as the C-24 – the Secretary-General, in remarks delivered by his Chef de Cabinet Courtenay Rattray, stressed that decolonization has been a core objective of the Organization “since its earliest days.”

“This Organization was created as a place where nations could meet as equals, not as rulers and ruled,” he said.

Yet, Mr. Guterres cautioned that the legacy of colonialism continues to shape present-day realities.

“The legacy of colonialism has left profound scars through deeply rooted mechanisms of economic exploitation, as well as in the form of racism, inequality and persistent exclusion from the decision-making bodies,” he said.

The C-24 was established by the General Assembly in 1961 to monitor progress towards granting independence to territories that have not yet attained “a full measure of self-government,” as defined under Chapter XI of the UN Charter. Its mandate stems from the landmark 1960 Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples.

United Nations Map of non-self-governing territories.

Intensifying climate threats

Many of the remaining territories are small islands facing intensifying climate threats.

Rising sea levels, coastal erosion and more frequent extreme weather events are damaging homes and infrastructure, undermining tourism and fisheries, and straining already limited public resources.

“The majority of the Territories are small islands,” he noted, urging the Special Committee to place “resilience and adaptation at the heart of your discussions.”

Call for inclusive dialogue

The Secretary-General outlined three priorities to guide the remaining decolonization process.

First, he called for “inclusive dialogue among Non-Self-Governing Territories, administering Powers, Member States, and all stakeholders,” stressing that each case must be addressed individually and “in accordance with the UN Charter, the 1960 Declaration, and the relevant resolutions of the General Assembly.”

Second, he underscored “the central role of young people,” saying that “the vision and leadership of the next generation is vital to building a productive and inclusive future.”

Third, he highlighted the urgency of climate action, particularly for island territories confronting existential risks.

articles.personality_title: UN calls for renewed effort to end colonial rule in 17 territories
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Since 1945, the United Nations has worked to help colonies become independent countries. Over 80 former colonies, with about 750 million people, have gained independence. However, 17 territories with nearly two million people still remain under colonial rule.

**What happened** – On Monday, UN Secretary-General António Guterres spoke at the opening of the 2026 session of the Special Committee on Decolonization (C-24). He urged countries and stakeholders to renew their commitment to finishing the process of decolonization. He highlighted the ongoing challenges these territories face, especially small island areas threatened by climate change.

**Impact** – This call is important because it focuses attention on the nearly two million people still living under colonial rule. It also recognizes that these territories suffer from economic problems, racism, and exclusion from decision-making. The Secretary-General emphasized the need for inclusive talks involving all parties, youth leadership, and climate action to protect vulnerable island communities.

**What's next step** – The Special Committee will continue its work by encouraging dialogue between the territories, the countries that govern them, and the UN. They will focus on each territory’s specific situation, support young leaders, and prioritize actions that help these places adapt to climate threats like rising sea levels.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN is renewing efforts to support self-governance and protect vulnerable communities in the last 17 colonial territories around the world.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’ONU appelle à un nouvel élan pour mettre fin à la colonisation dans 17 territoires
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis 1945, l’ONU aide les colonies à devenir des pays indépendants. Plus de 80 anciennes colonies, avec environ 750 millions d’habitants, ont obtenu leur indépendance. Pourtant, 17 territoires abritant près de deux millions de personnes restent sous domination coloniale.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lundi, le secrétaire général de l’ONU, António Guterres, a pris la parole lors de l’ouverture de la session 2026 du Comité spécial de décolonisation (C-24). Il a appelé à un engagement renouvelé pour achever le processus de décolonisation. Il a souligné les défis actuels, notamment le changement climatique qui menace particulièrement les petits territoires insulaires.

**Impact** – Cet appel est important car il attire l’attention sur les presque deux millions de personnes encore sous domination coloniale. Il reconnaît aussi que ces territoires souffrent de problèmes économiques, de racisme et d’exclusion des prises de décision. Le secrétaire général a insisté sur la nécessité de dialogues inclusifs, sur le rôle des jeunes et sur des actions climatiques pour protéger ces communautés vulnérables.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Comité spécial poursuivra son travail en encourageant le dialogue entre les territoires, les pays administrateurs et l’ONU. Il tiendra compte de la situation spécifique de chaque territoire, soutiendra les jeunes leaders et mettra l’accent sur l’adaptation aux menaces climatiques comme la montée du niveau de la mer.

**En une phrase** – L’ONU relance ses efforts pour soutenir l’autonomie et protéger les communautés vulnérables dans les 17 derniers territoires coloniaux du monde.
articles.personality_title_es: ONU pide renovar esfuerzos para poner fin al colonialismo en 17 territorios
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Desde 1945, las Naciones Unidas han ayudado a que las colonias se conviertan en países independientes. Más de 80 antiguas colonias, con alrededor de 750 millones de personas, han logrado la independencia. Sin embargo, 17 territorios con casi dos millones de habitantes siguen bajo dominio colonial.

**Qué pasó** – El lunes, el Secretario General de la ONU, António Guterres, habló en la apertura de la sesión 2026 del Comité Especial de Descolonización (C-24). Llamó a renovar el compromiso para completar el proceso de descolonización. Destacó los desafíos actuales, especialmente para las pequeñas islas amenazadas por el cambio climático.

**Impacto** – Este llamado es importante porque pone atención en las casi dos millones de personas que aún viven bajo dominio colonial. También reconoce que estos territorios enfrentan problemas económicos, racismo y exclusión de la toma de decisiones. El Secretario General subrayó la necesidad de diálogos inclusivos, el papel de los jóvenes y acciones climáticas para proteger a estas comunidades vulnerables.

**Próximo paso** – El Comité Especial continuará su trabajo promoviendo el diálogo entre los territorios, los países administradores y la ONU. Se enfocarán en la situación particular de cada territorio, apoyarán a los líderes jóvenes y priorizarán acciones para ayudar a adaptarse a las amenazas climáticas como la subida del nivel del mar.

**Resumen en una frase** – La ONU renueva esfuerzos para apoyar la autogobernanza y proteger a las comunidades vulnerables en los últimos 17 territorios coloniales del mundo.
